text: You okay?

I'm sorry.

Salen's changes are not hard because of my ASD.

are all inferior to what we had before.

I've seen you adapt to things before.
Like the toilet paper and how I cut avocados.

Maybe you should see what the others think first.
If the studies prove I'm right,
what others think doesn't matter.
To you, yes,

To get Salen to change her mind,

That is...
Good advice.
Uh, thank you.
You're welcome.
And thank you for taking care of these.
I will mail them out today.
This is so exciting.
Yes, it is.
Well, you signed a year lease.

I definitely liked not watching TV in bed.

There's new soap?

And you're still experiencing the seizures.
No.

Well, if it's working so well, why does Dr. Karlson want to take it out?
The company that made the implant
wants to turn it off.
That doesn't make any sense.
They can't force her to have it removed.
Yeah, but they can stop

The implant's an experimental prototype.
Worked only for a tiny percentage of patients,

It's capitalism.
Karlson's right. It has to come out.

She already had one. Didn't work.
I was thinking laser interstitial thermal therapy.
Would only be partially effective.
She was having 50 seizures a day.
"Partially" can make a big difference in her life.
Not big enough.

could leave her a hemiplegic.
Could happen... If another surgeon was doing it.
I'm confident with you at the helm, we can pull it off.
Trying to "manage up"

But I'll never turn down a good idea

And it's actually a great idea.
I see you've scheduled a surgery

Yes, the client consented,

Fantastic. Have you also run it past legal?
Why would we do that?
Because we could get sued and it sounds risky.
Is there a Plan B?
There isn't a comparable option. Not even remotely?
Well, as is usually the case, there is a less risky option,

Seems better to start with an approach

But as long as it's covered by insurance...
It's your call.
That was weird.
More like totally inappropriate.

Marcus.
Thanks for coming to me.

Not bad.
